title: Heart Attack Emergency Signs
content: A heart attack is a medical emergency. Every minute matters. If you think you or someone else is having a heart attack, call emergency services (112 in Turkey) immediately. Do not wait to see if symptoms improve.
symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort (pressure, squeezing, fullness, or pain)
Pain or discomfort in arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach
Shortness of breath (with or without chest pain)
Women may have more subtle symptoms
what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY - do not delay
Do not drive yourself - call ambulance or have someone drive you
Rest in a comfortable position (sitting up may be easier for breathing)
Loosen tight clothing
Stay calm and try to remain still
If unconscious and not breathing, begin CPR if trained
Use AED (automated external defibrillator) if available and trained
do_not: Do NOT delay calling emergency services
Do NOT drive yourself to hospital
Do NOT ignore symptoms hoping they'll pass
Do NOT take aspirin without medical guidance (see safety note)
Do NOT give anything by mouth if person is unconscious
aspirin_safety_note: Emergency services may advise chewing aspirin. However, do NOT take aspirin without being advised to, as it can be dangerous for some people: those with aspirin allergy, bleeding disorders, stomach ulcers, or already taking blood thinners. WAIT for medical guidance.
time_critical: With a heart attack, every minute counts. The faster treatment begins, the better the outcome. 'Time is muscle' - heart muscle dies without blood flow.

title: Stroke Emergency Signs (FAST)
content: Stroke is a medical emergency where blood supply to the brain is interrupted. Use FAST to remember warning signs: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency. Brain cells die every minute without treatment.
symptoms: Face drooping on one side (ask person to smile)
Speech difficulty (slurred, confused, unable to speak)
Sudden severe headache with no known cause
Vision problems (sudden blurred or lost vision)
Trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance

fast_test.F: FACE - Ask the person to smile. Does one side of the face droop?
fast_test.A: ARMS - Ask them to raise both arms. Does one arm drift downward?
fast_test.S: SPEECH - Ask them to repeat a simple phrase. Is speech slurred or strange?
fast_test.T: TIME - If you see ANY of these signs, call 112 IMMEDIATELY

what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY - time is critical
Note the exact time symptoms started (crucial for treatment)
Keep the person calm and comfortable
Do not give food or water (swallowing may be affected)
Lay person on their side if vomiting or unconscious
Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
Do not give any medications
do_not: Do NOT delay - every minute matters
Do NOT give food, water, or any medication
Do NOT let them 'sleep it off'
Do NOT wait to see if symptoms improve
time_critical: Brain cells die at a rate of about 1.9 million per minute during a stroke. Treatment within 3-4.5 hours with clot-busting drugs can significantly improve outcomes.

title: Severe Breathing Difficulty Emergency
content: Severe breathing difficulty is a medical emergency. It can be caused by asthma attacks, allergic reactions (anaphylaxis), heart problems, or other conditions. If someone cannot breathe properly, call emergency services immediately.
symptoms: Struggling to breathe or gasping for air
Cannot speak in full sentences due to breathlessness
Blue or grey lips, face, or fingernails (cyanosis)
Confusion or drowsiness due to lack of oxygen
what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY
Help person sit upright (usually easier to breathe)
Loosen any tight clothing around neck and chest
If asthmatic: help use their reliever inhaler (usually blue)
If known severe allergy: help use EpiPen if available and trained
Stay calm and reassure the person
If choking on object: perform back blows and Heimlich maneuver if trained
Open windows for fresh air if helpful
do_not: Do NOT lay person flat if they're struggling to breathe
Do NOT give food or water
Do NOT leave them alone
Do NOT delay calling for help
asthma_note: If person has asthma: help them use their reliever inhaler (usually blue). Give 1 puff every 30-60 seconds, up to 10 puffs. If no improvement after 10 puffs, or if you don't have an inhaler, call 112.

title: Severe Bleeding Emergency
content: Severe bleeding can be life-threatening and requires immediate action to stop blood loss while waiting for emergency services. Apply direct pressure and call for help immediately.
symptoms: Pale, cold, or clammy skin (signs of shock)
what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY
Apply direct, firm pressure with clean cloth, bandage, or clothing
Press firmly and continuously - do not lift to check
If blood soaks through, add more cloth on top (don't remove first layer)
If possible and no broken bones, elevate injured area above heart level
Keep person warm and calm
Monitor for signs of shock
do_not: Do NOT remove embedded objects (apply pressure around them)
Do NOT apply a tourniquet unless trained and bleeding is life-threatening from a limb
Do NOT remove blood-soaked bandages (add more on top)
Do NOT give food or water
shock_warning: Severe blood loss can cause shock. Signs include: pale/cold/clammy skin, rapid weak pulse, rapid breathing, confusion. Lay person down, elevate legs (if no broken bones), keep warm, and call 112.

title: Severe Allergic Reaction (Anaphylaxis)
source_name: American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology
content: Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to an allergen. It requires immediate epinephrine (adrenaline) and emergency care.
symptoms: Difficulty breathing, wheezing, shortness of breath
Swelling of throat, tongue, or lips
Feeling of impending doom or anxiety
common_triggers: Foods: nuts (especially peanuts), shellfish, fish, eggs, milk, wheat, soy
Insect stings: bees, wasps, hornets, fire ants
what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY - this is life-threatening
Use EpiPen (epinephrine auto-injector) if available - inject into outer thigh
Help person lie down with legs elevated (unless breathing difficult)
If breathing difficult, allow to sit up
Loosen tight clothing
Stay with person and monitor breathing
Second dose of epinephrine after 5-15 minutes if no improvement
Be prepared to start CPR if they become unresponsive
do_not: Do NOT delay giving epinephrine if available and person is having anaphylaxis
Do NOT assume symptoms will improve on their own
Do NOT give antihistamines instead of epinephrine for severe reactions
Do NOT have person sit up if feeling faint (lay flat with legs raised)
epipen_note: EpiPen is injected into the outer thigh (can be through clothing). Hold in place for 10 seconds. Massage area after. Call 112 even after using EpiPen - effects wear off and reaction may return.

title: Unconscious Person
content: Finding someone unconscious requires quick assessment and action. Check if they're breathing and responsive, and call for emergency help immediately. Be prepared to perform CPR if needed.
what_to_do: Check scene is safe for you and the person
Tap shoulders firmly and shout 'Are you okay?'
CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY (or have someone else call)
Check for breathing (look, listen, feel for 10 seconds)
If breathing normally: place in recovery position
If NOT breathing or only gasping: start CPR immediately
Send someone to get AED (automated external defibrillator) if available

cpr_basics.rate: Push hard and fast: 100-120 compressions per minute
cpr_basics.depth: Press down at least 5cm (2 inches) on center of chest
cpr_basics.hands_only: If not trained in rescue breaths, do hands-only CPR (compressions only)
cpr_basics.continue: Continue until help arrives or person starts breathing

recovery_position: Use if person is breathing but unconscious
Place nearest arm at right angle to body, palm up
Bring far arm across chest, hold hand against near cheek
Pull far knee up, foot flat on ground
Roll person toward you onto their side
Tilt head back slightly to keep airway open
do_not: Do NOT move them if you suspect spinal injury (unless in danger)
Do NOT put anything in their mouth
Do NOT leave them alone
Do NOT delay calling for help

title: Poisoning Emergency
source_name: American Association of Poison Control Centers
content: Poisoning can occur from medications, household chemicals, plants, or food. Symptoms vary based on the substance. Call emergency services immediately if poisoning is suspected, especially if the person is unconscious, having seizures, or having difficulty breathing.
symptoms: Burns or redness around mouth (chemical ingestion)
what_to_do: CALL 112 if person is unconscious, having seizures, or difficulty breathing
Try to identify what was taken, when, and how much
Bring the container/substance to hospital if possible
If conscious and alert, call Poison Control for guidance
Do not induce vomiting unless specifically told to by medical professionals
If chemical on skin: remove contaminated clothing, rinse skin with water
If chemical in eye: rinse with clean water for 15-20 minutes
do_not: Do NOT induce vomiting unless told to by medical professionals
Do NOT give anything to eat or drink unless advised
Do NOT try to 'neutralize' poison with other substances
Do NOT wait for symptoms before calling for help
bring_to_hospital: If possible, bring the container, pill bottle, or substance with you to the hospital. This helps medical staff provide proper treatment.

title: Seizure Emergency
content: A seizure is caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Most seizures end on their own within a few minutes. The main goal is to keep the person safe and prevent injury during the seizure.
what_to_do: Stay calm - most seizures end within 1-3 minutes
Time the seizure
Clear area of hard or sharp objects
Protect their head with something soft
Gently guide them to the floor if standing
Turn them on their side (recovery position) if possible
Stay with them until fully alert
Speak calmly and reassuringly as they recover
call_112_if: Person is pregnant, diabetic, or has heart disease
Person has breathing difficulties after seizure
do_not: Do NOT hold them down or restrain movements
Do NOT put anything in their mouth
Do NOT try to stop the jerking movements
Do NOT give food or water until fully alert
Do NOT leave them alone
after_seizure: Person may be confused, tired, or have a headache after seizure. Stay with them, speak calmly, and help them get oriented. They may not remember the seizure.

title: Mental Health Crisis - Suicide / Self-Harm
title_tr: Ruh Sağlığı Krizi - İntihar / Kendine Zarar Verme
content: If you or someone you know is having thoughts of suicide or self-harm, this is a crisis that requires immediate help. You are not alone, and help is available. Please reach out to emergency services or a crisis hotline immediately.
crisis_info: Acil durumlarda 112'yi arayın. Alo 183 (Aile ve Sosyal Hizmetler danışma hattı) veya en yakın ruh sağlığı merkezine başvurun.
symptoms: Thoughts of wanting to die or end life
Talking about being a burden to others
what_to_do: If immediate danger: CALL 112 NOW
Stay with the person - do not leave them alone
Remove access to harmful objects (medications, sharp objects, firearms)
Listen without judgment - let them talk
Call emergency: 112, or contact Alo 183 (family services helpline)
Take all talk of suicide seriously
Encourage professional help
Express that you care and want to help
do_not: Do NOT leave them alone if in immediate danger
Do NOT promise to keep it secret - get help
Do NOT judge or dismiss their feelings
Do NOT argue or try to talk them out of their feelings
Do NOT give advice like 'just think positive'

title: Pediatric High Fever Emergency
content: High fever in children, especially above 39-40°C (102-104°F), can be a sign of serious infection and may require emergency care. Young infants with fever are especially at risk and need immediate medical attention.
symptoms: Fever in infant under 3 months at any temperature above 38°C
Child is unusually drowsy or difficult to wake
Purple spots or rash that doesn't fade when pressed
what_to_do: CALL 112 if: fever above 40°C, difficulty breathing, purple rash, extreme lethargy
Check temperature with thermometer
Give appropriate dose of paracetamol or ibuprofen (not aspirin for children)
Remove excess clothing
Give plenty of fluids
Keep child comfortable
Monitor for warning signs
Seek medical attention promptly
do_not: Do NOT give aspirin to children (risk of Reye's syndrome)
Do NOT bundle up a feverish child
Do NOT use cold baths or alcohol rubs
Do NOT ignore fever in infants under 3 months

title: Pregnancy Bleeding Emergency
source_name: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
content: Bleeding during pregnancy can be a sign of serious complications including miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, or placental problems. Any significant bleeding during pregnancy requires immediate medical evaluation.
symptoms: Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad in an hour)
what_to_do: CALL 112 or go to emergency room immediately
Note amount of bleeding (how many pads soaked)
Save any tissue passed for medical examination
Lie down and rest
Do not insert anything into vagina
Bring pregnancy records if available
do_not: Do NOT ignore any bleeding during pregnancy
Do NOT wait to see if bleeding stops
Do NOT use tampons
Do NOT have intercourse

title: Sudden Vision Loss Emergency
content: Sudden vision loss is a medical emergency that can indicate stroke, retinal detachment, or other serious conditions. Immediate treatment may be needed to preserve vision. Every minute counts.
symptoms: Sudden complete or partial vision loss in one or both eyes
Sudden appearance of floaters or flashes
what_to_do: CALL 112 or go to emergency room IMMEDIATELY
Note exactly when vision loss started
Cover the unaffected eye to check if both eyes are affected
Do not drive
Do not rub the eye
Bring list of medications and medical history
do_not: Do NOT wait to see if vision returns
Do NOT assume it will get better on its own
Do NOT rub or press on the eye
Do NOT delay seeking care

title: Severe Hypoglycemia (Low Blood Sugar) Emergency
title_tr: Ciddi Hipoglisemi (Düşük Kan Şekeri) Acil Durumu
content: Severe hypoglycemia (very low blood sugar) is a medical emergency, especially in diabetics. It can cause confusion, loss of consciousness, and seizures. Quick treatment with sugar/glucose is essential, and emergency help may be needed.
what_to_do: If conscious: give fast-acting sugar immediately (glucose tablets, juice, regular soda, candy)
15-20 grams of fast-acting carbs
Wait 15 minutes and recheck
If unconscious: CALL 112 immediately
Do not give food or drink to unconscious person
If glucagon kit available and trained: administer glucagon
Place unconscious person on their side
Monitor breathing
do_not: Do NOT give food or drink if person is unconscious or confused
Do NOT give insulin for low blood sugar
Do NOT leave person alone
Do NOT assume symptoms will resolve on their own

title: Airway Obstruction / Throat Swelling Emergency
title_tr: Hava Yolu Tıkanması / Boğaz Şişmesi Acil Durumu
content: Airway obstruction or throat swelling is a life-threatening emergency. Whether from choking, allergic reaction, or infection, an obstructed airway requires immediate action. Every second counts.
symptoms: Cannot breathe or severe difficulty breathing
what_to_do: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY
If choking on food/object: perform back blows and Heimlich maneuver
If allergic reaction: use EpiPen if available
Do not give food or water
Keep person calm
If unconscious and not breathing: start CPR
Monitor airway continuously
do_not: Do NOT leave person alone
Do NOT try to remove object with fingers (may push deeper)
Do NOT give anything by mouth
Do NOT delay calling emergency services
